t: Job 6
But*p Job answered and said,
Oh*p that my grief were thoroughly weighed, and my calamity laid in the balances together!
For*p now it would be heavier than the sand of the sea: therefore my words are swallowed up.
For*p the arrows of the Almighty are within me, the poison whereof drinketh up my spirit: the terrors of God do set themselves in array against me.
Doth*p the wild ass bray when he hath grass? or loweth the ox over his fodder?
Can*p that which is unsavoury be eaten without salt? or is there any taste in the white of an egg?
The*p things that my soul refused to touch are as my sorrowful meat.
Oh*p that I might have my request; and that God would grant me the thing that I long for!
Even*p that it would please God to destroy me; that he would let loose his hand, and cut me off!
Then*p should I yet have comfort; yea, I would harden myself in sorrow: let him not spare; for I have not concealed the words of the Holy One.
What*p is my strength, that I should hope? and what is mine end, that I should prolong my life?
Is*p my strength the strength of stones? or is my flesh of brass?
Is*p not my help in me? and is wisdom driven quite from me?
To*p him that is afflicted pity should be shewed from his friend; but he forsaketh the fear of the Almighty.
My*p brethren have dealt deceitfully as a brook, and as the stream of brooks they pass away;
Which*p are blackish by reason of the ice, and wherein the snow is hid:
What*p time they wax warm, they vanish: when it is hot, they are consumed out of their place.
The*p paths of their way are turned aside; they go to nothing, and perish.
The*p troops of Tema looked, the companies of Sheba waited for them.
They*p were confounded because they had hoped; they came thither, and were ashamed.
For*p now ye are nothing; ye see my casting down, and are afraid.
Did*p I say, Bring unto me? or, Give a reward for me of your substance?
Or,*p Deliver me from the enemy's hand? or, Redeem me from the hand of the mighty?
Teach*p me, and I will hold my tongue: and cause me to understand wherein I have erred.
How*p forcible are right words! but what doth your arguing reprove?
Do*p ye imagine to reprove words, and the speeches of one that is desperate, which are as wind?
Yea,*p ye overwhelm the fatherless, and ye dig a pit for your friend.
Now*p therefore be content, look upon me; for it is evident unto you if I lie.
Return,*p I pray you, let it not be iniquity; yea, return again, my righteousness is in it.
Is*p there iniquity in my tongue? cannot my taste discern perverse things?
